data.description: In 1857, businessman and transportation entrepreneur John Butterfield was awarded a contract to establish an overland mail route between the eastern United States and growing populations in the Far West. What became known as the Butterfield Overland Trail made an arcing sweep across the southern rim of the country. Stagecoaches left twice a week carrying passengers, freight, and mail.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 3,300 miles of historic trail.

operatingHours.description: The Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead, it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail

images.caption: A site along the Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail

images.caption: Visit the Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail to a take a step back in time.

images.title: Saguaro Forest on the Butterfield Overland NHT
images.altText: A forest of tall, multi-armed Saguaro cacti stretches out towards the horizon.
images.caption: The Butterfield Overland NHT traversed thousands of miles of desert on the delivery route.

images.title: Butterfield Station site at Picacho Village in Dona Ana County, NM

images.caption: The Butterfield Overland NHT passes through modern city neighborhoods.

data.name: Butterfield Overland

data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

data.description: Gateway Arch National Park commemorates President Jefferson’s vision of a continental nation, the individuals and cultural groups who helped shape its history, St. Louis’ role in westward expansion, and Dred and Harriet Scott, who sued for their freedom in the Old Courthouse.

entranceFees.description:
Prices vary by date of visit. 

Begin your tour with an interactive pre-boarding experience featuring 60s-inspired animation and Gateway Arch trivia. Then, be transported 630 feet to the top of Arch for exhilarating views. Please allow 45 - 60 minutes for your Tram Ride to the Top experience.

Adult (16 and up): Starting at $15

Child (3-15): Starting at $11

Infant (2 and under): FREE

Park Pass Holder: Starting at $12

Tickets available at www.gatewayarch.com
entranceFees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location

data.directionsInfo: For directions click on the provided link

operatingHours.description: The Gateway Arch is open year-round, closed only on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year’s Day. Summer Hours (9am-6pm, Sunday through Thursday and 9am-8pm Friday and Saturday) run the Friday before Memorial Day through Labor Day weekend and are the primary visitor season. During Regular Hours (the day after Labor Day through Friday before Memorial Day) we are open from 9am to 6pm. Around the holidays we occasionally have extended hours.
operatingHours.name: Gateway Arch Visitor Center, Museum, and Ride to the Top

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open daily, year round.
operatingHours.name: Gateway Arch Grounds

operatingHours.description: The Old Courthouse renovation is complete, and it is now open to the public.
operatingHours.name: Old Courthouse

data.description: The young child known as the "Plant Doctor" tended his secret garden while observing the day-to-day operations of a 19th century farm. Nature and nurture ultimately influenced George on his quest for education to becoming a renowned agricultural scientist, educator, and humanitarian.
data.directionsInfo: From Interstate 44, drive south on either: Interstate 49: Exit at Diamond (exit 35), then drive five miles east on highway V, and drive ¾ mile south on Carver Road to the park entrance. Highway 59: In Diamond, turn west on highway V and drive for 2 miles, and drive ¾ mile south on Carver Road to the park entrance.

operatingHours.description: George Washington Carver National Monument is open 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM daily, except Thanksgiving Day, December 25, and January 1.  There is no park entrance fee.
operatingHours.name: George Washington Carver National Monument

images.title: Statue of young George Washington Carver on the Carver trail
images.altText: Bronze status of young George Washington Carver atop a large boulder, on the Carver trail.
images.caption: "Boy Carver Statue," sculpted by Robert Amendola in 1960.

images.title: George Washington Carver NM Entrance
images.altText: An entrance sign to George Washington Carver National Monument with wildflower and plants.
images.caption: Entrance sign to George Washington Carver NM will wildflower and plants.

images.title: George Washington Carver NM Prairie
images.altText: Sunflowers in a prairie at George Washington Carver NM.
images.caption: Prairie at George Washington Carver NM with sunflowers.

images.title: George Washington Carver NM Science Classroom
images.altText: Park's science classroom with lab tables and wall exhibits on George Washington Carver.
images.caption: George Washington Carver NM science classroom modeled after one of the George Washington Carver's lab at Tuskegee Institute.

images.title: George Washington Carver Bust
images.altText: A cast concrete bust of George Washington Carver and prairie in the background.
images.caption: A cast concrete bust for George Washington Carver by Audrey Corwin, 1952.

data.weatherInfo: George Washington Carver National Monument is located in southwestern Missouri just outside of Diamond and about 10 miles from Joplin. Summer temperatures generally range from 75-100 degrees with high humidity. Winter temperatures generally range from 0-50 degrees with periods of intermittent freezing.
data.name: George Washington Carver

data.fullName: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
data.description: President Harry S Truman took America from its traditional isolationism into the age of international involvement. Despite his power, he never forgot where he came from. Today, visitors can experience the surroundings Truman knew as a young man of modest ambition through his political career and final years as a former president.

emailAddresses.description:
Please note this email address is not monitored on weekends and holidays.

Emails may need a week or so for us to be able to respond to you; but we will do the best we can!

data.directionsInfo: The Visitor Center is located at 223 North Main Street. From the north or south, take I-435 to Truman Road (State Hwy 12), exit 60. Travel east on Truman Road three miles; you'll pass the Truman Home at Delaware Street. From the east or west, take I-70 to the Noland Road exit (12). Travel north on Noland Road four miles to Truman Road. Turn west on Truman Road and travel two blocks. The Truman Home is five blocks to the west of the visitor center.

operatingHours.description:
Take a guided tour of the historic Truman Home. With thousands of artifacts on display, the home is an insightful glimpse into the personal lives of the Trumans. 

 Visitors must stop by the visitor center first to obtain tickets to tour the Home. Tickets are not issued at the Truman Home itself.

All tickets first come, first served on the day of. We can't make exceptions.

The Noland Home is self guided...you can stop in before or after your tour. (We recommend before.)
operatingHours.name: Truman Home, Visitor Center - Independence

operatingHours.description:
The Truman Farm in Grandview, Missouri is located at 12301 Blue Ridge Blvd.

Due to ongoing foundation construction, the park is suspending Truman Farm Home tours. The grounds are open year-round for self-guided tours. Audio tours are available on the NPS App.
operatingHours.name: Truman Farm - Grandview

addresses.line1: 223 North Main Street (Visitor Center/ Truman Home Ticketing Station)

images.title: The Truman Home
images.altText: The Truman home near sunset.
images.caption: Although Harry Truman was a 20th century president, his home was from the Victorian era.

images.title: The Truman Farm Home
images.altText: The Truman Farm Home sits behind Autumn trees.
images.caption: From when he was 22 until he was 33 years old, Harry Truman lived on his grandmother's farm.

images.title: The Noland Home
images.altText: The Noland home sits across the street from the Truman home.
images.caption: Harry Truman's cousins, the Nolands, lived right across the street from him.

images.title: The George Wallace Home
images.altText: The George Wallace home with the Truman home in the background.
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, George, and his wife, May, lived right behind the Truman home.

images.title: 219 North Delaware Street...Then and Now
images.altText: The Truman Home, Then and Now!
images.caption: Once the home of a flour mill partner, it later was the home of a president.

images.title: The Frank Wallace Home
images.altText: The Frank Wallace home where Bess Truman's brother lived.
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, Frank, and his wife Natalie, lived in this small bungalow right behind the Truman home.

data.weatherInfo: Located on the western edge of Missouri, the park enjoys each of the four seasons. Early spring brings frequent and rapid fluctuations in weather. The summer season has warm days, periods of high heat and humidity, and mild nights. The fall season is normally mild with sunny days and cool nights. Winters can be cold. The January low averages 21 degrees. The area receives a yearly average of 37 inches of rain per year and around 18 inches of snow. Our zip code is 64050 if you wish to go to www.weather.gov
data.name: Harry S Truman

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.description: Imagine yourself an emigrant headed for Oregon: would promises of lush farmlands and a new beginning lure you to leave home and walk for weeks? More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states and serve as reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.
data.directionsInfo: More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states- reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.

operatingHours.description: The Oregon National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Oregon National Historic Trail

data.description: Ozark National Scenic Riverways is the first national park area to protect a river system. The Current and Jacks Fork rivers are two of the finest floating rivers found anywhere. Spring-fed, cold and clear: they are a delight to canoe, swim, boat, or fish. Besides these two famous rivers, the park is home to hundreds of freshwater springs, caves, trails, and historic sites such as Alley Mill.

emailAddresses.description: This email will be received by our interpretation team.

data.directionsInfo: Visitor centers can be found at the following locations: Big Spring Entrance Station - 3 miles south of Van Buren on Highway 103 Alley Mill & Store - 12185 Alley Hollow Road Round Spring Ranger Station - 13209 Round Spring Campground Rd Administrative offices for Ozark National Scenic Riverways are located at 404 Watercress Drive, Van Buren, MO 63965. This location does not offer a visitor center - tourists should instead go to the Big Spring Entrance Station.

operatingHours.description: Generally, the park grounds are open 24-hours a day throughout the year. Some visitor centers will have different hours depending on season and staff availability. Likewise, certain roads, trails, or river access points may be seasonally closed.
operatingHours.name: Ozark National Scenic Riverways

addresses.line1: Multiple locations - Alley Spring Visitor Center: 12185 Alley Hollow Road, Eminence, MO 65466
addresses.line3: Administrative Headquarters: 404 Watercress Drive, Van Buren MO 63965
addresses.line2: Big Spring Entrance Station: Hwy 103, Van Buren, MO 63965

data.weatherInfo: Ozark National Scenic Riverways is located in southeastern Missouri. Summer temperatures generally range from 75-100 degrees (°F) with high humidity. Winter temperatures generally range from 0-50 (°F) degrees with periods of intermittent freezing and snow. Periods of excessive heat are typical in summer, while heavy rains or flooding can occur throughout the year. Be sure to plan accordingly when camping, hiking, or floating.
data.name: Ozark

data.description: It is hard to believe that young men once rode horses to carry mail from Missouri to California in the unprecedented time of only 10 days. This relay system along the Pony Express National Historic Trail in eight states was the most direct and practical means of east-west communications before the telegraph.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Pony Express National Historic Trail over the 1,800-mile historic route that crosses 8 states.

operatingHours.description: The Pony Express National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Pony Express National Historic Trail

images.altText: A rider in a red vest on a horse in a grassy patch surrounded by sagebrush with clouds in the sky.
images.caption: A National Pony Express Association rider poses at Simpson Springs in Utah.

images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important landmark on the trail in Wyoming.

images.caption: A Pony Express rider silhouette can be found at the Schelbourne Station site in Nevada.

images.altText: A tall obelisk monument with bronze plaques sits on a paved pathway in front of a building.
images.caption: A monument and plaque about the Pony Express can be found at Fort Laramie in Wyoming.

images.altText: A large brick historic stable.
images.caption: Visit the historic stables in St. Joseph, Missouri.

data.description: You can almost hear the whoops and cries of "All's set!" as trail hands hitched their oxen to freight wagons carrying cargo between western Missouri and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Follow the Santa Fe National Historic Trail through five states and you'll find adventure and evidence of past travelers who made this remarkable trip before you!
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail over the 900-mile historic route that crosses five states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Santa Fe National Historic Trail

images.title: Cimarron National Grassland
images.altText: Warm light from the setting sun gives an orange glow to a rock bluff overlooking a grassland.
images.caption: Visit Cimarron National Grassland to experience the Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Neosho River Crossing, Council Grove
images.altText: A wide river with green grass parks on the side.
images.caption: The Neosho River in Council Grove was an important crossing on the trail.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site, La Junta, Colorado
images.altText: emigrant wagons pulled by oxen and horses cross the prairie with people walking alongside
images.caption: After spending weeks crossing hundreds of miles of lonely and desolate prairie, a trading post appeared: a welcome respite where travelers could repair their wagon and trade for coffee, sugar, blankets, and ammunition.

images.title: Wagon Mound, Mora County, New Mexico
images.altText: desert landscape with a mountain that looks like a wagon from a distance, verdant green grasses
images.caption: Wagon Mound was a landmark on the Santa Fe Trail. Coming from Raton, New Mexico, travelers looked for this wagon-like hill to know that they were close to Santa Fe. Leave Interstate 25 at the village of Wagon Mound in Mora County to find this landmark.

images.title: Fort Union, New Mexico
images.altText: A stone path leads into the distance next to adobe ruins.
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail traverses through Fort Union.

data.description: Established by 1750, Ste. Geneviève was the first permanent European settlement in Missouri. Early French Canadian settlers were drawn here by the rich agricultural land known as Le Grand Champ (the Big Field). After the flood of 1785, the town relocated to its present location on higher ground approximately three miles to the northwest of its original site.
data.directionsInfo: From north of Ste. Genevieve (e.g. St. Louis), take I-55 South to exit 150. Follow MO-32 East for about 4 miles. Turn right on Market Street. From south of Ste. Genevieve (e.g. Cape Girardeau), take I-55 North to exit 150. Follow MO-32 East for about 4 miles. Turn right on Market Street. From southern Illinois, you can also take the Ste. Genevieve - Modoc Ferry across the Mississippi. Please visit http://stegenmodocferry.com/ for hours and rates.

operatingHours.description:
Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park and the Ste. Genevieve Welcome Center is open from 9AM to 5PM daily with the exception of Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day. 

For program information and access to historic structures, please check with staff at the Ste. Genevieve Welcome Center, 573-880-7189.
operatingHours.name: Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park

images.caption: Bauvais-Amoureux House

images.caption: Tours are usually offered daily of the Jean Baptiste Valle House.

images.caption: Take a break in the Jean Baptiste Valle Rose Garden.

images.caption: Get park and city information at the Ste. Genevieve Welcome Center

data.weatherInfo: The weather in Ste. Genevieve is typical of a midwestern climate. High heat and humidity, severe thunderstorms, snow and ice, and extreme cold are all possible depending upon the season. The average high in July is 88 degrees and the average low in January is 22 degrees. The area averages 41 inches of precipitation annually. Please plan your visit accordingly.
data.name: Ste. Geneviève

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears

data.fullName: Ulysses S Grant National Historic Site
data.description: Ulysses S. Grant is known as the victorious Civil War general who saved the Union and the 18th President of the United States. He first met Julia Dent, his future wife, at her family home, named White Haven. From 1854 to 1859 the Dents, Grants and an enslaved African-American workforce lived on the property.
data.directionsInfo: Ulysses S. Grant is located in south St. Louis County on Grant Road, near Gravois Road to the south. Watson Road is to the north, I-270 is to the west, and Laclede Station Road is to the east.

operatingHours.description: Ulysses S. Grant National Historic Site’s hours of operation are 9AM – 5PM, with the last tour of the historic house at 4 pm.
operatingHours.name: Ulysses S. Grant National Historic Site

images.title: White Haven in Autumn
images.altText: View of house with fence. Autumn colored leaves on trees
images.caption: White Haven is picturesque in all seasons, but in the fall the trees are especially beautiful.

images.title: White Haven
images.altText: view of house from side and back. The house has several additions. Stone summer kitchen on right
images.caption: Behind the house is stone summer kitchen.

images.title: Outbuildings
images.altText: To the left is the ice house and to right is chicken house.
images.caption: Ice house and chicken house behind the main house.

images.title: Tack Room
images.altText: Saddles in tack room
images.caption: The historic stable tack room.

images.title: Museum Exhibits
images.altText: boy looking at touchscreen in museum
images.caption: The interactive museum is located in the historic stable.

images.title: Winter at White Haven
images.altText: Historic green house with snow on ground
images.caption: Visiting the park in the winter can be beautiful and peaceful.

images.title: White Haven in Early Spring
images.altText: View of house from front with budding tree branch in foreground that is also covered in ice.
images.caption: Snowfall in early spring.

data.weatherInfo: St. Louis weather can be uncomfortable and occasionally severe, so please plan your visit accordingly. High heat and humidity, severe thunderstorms, snow and ice, and extreme cold are all possible depending upon the season. For an update of inclement weather conditions which may affect your visit, call (314)842-1867 and follow the instructions to connect to the inclement weather report.
data.name: Ulysses S Grant

data.description: Wilson's Creek was the first major Civil War battle fought west of the Mississippi River, and where the first Union general was killed in action. The costly Southern victory on August 10, 1861, focused national attention on the war in Missouri. Wilson’s Creek National Battlefield commemorates and interprets the battle within the context of the war in the Trans-Mississippi West.
data.directionsInfo: From I-44: exit at Exit 70 (Missouri Highway MM). Continue south to U.S. Highway 60. Proceed through the intersection. Continue 1/2 mile to Missouri Highway ZZ. Turn right on ZZ. Continue south to Farm Road 182 (Elm Street). At the roundabout, take the third exit; the entrance to the battlefield is on the right.

exceptions.name: HOLIDAY CLOSURE VISITOR CENTER - THANKSGIVING DAY
HOLIDAY CLOSURE of Visitor Center - CHRISTMAS DAY
HOLIDAY CLOSURE of Visitor Center - NEW YEAR'S DAY

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open from 1/2 hour before sunrise until 1/2 hour after sunset. This includes non-motorized and pedestrian access to the tour road. Motorized access to the tour road begins at 8:00 am daily when the automated entrance gate will open. The visitor center and museum hours are 9:00 am to 5:00 pm daily, seven days a week.
operatingHours.name: STANDARD HOURS (TOUR ROAD)

images.title: Moonlight Tour
images.altText: Men in reproduction uniforms talk around a campfire
images.caption: Living history volunteers act out a scene during the annual Moonlight Tours event

images.title: Edwards Cabin
images.altText: Women in reproduction historic dress sit and stand on porch of old cabin
images.caption: Living history volunteers give demonstration at the historic Edwards Cabin

images.title: Lyon Marker
images.altText: A stone marker with engraving sits in front of a wooden fence and trees
images.caption: The 1928 Lyon Marker commemorates General Nathaniel Lyon, the first Union general to die in the Civil War.

images.title: Henry Rifle
images.altText: The receiver of an 1864 rifle shows decorative engraving with the original owner's name
images.caption: A rare 1864 Henry repeating rifle from the park's museum collection belonged to Missouri Civil War veteran George W. Fulton

images.title: Tour Road
images.altText: A man and woman walk with their dog on a paved road edged by trees and fields
images.caption: Visitors enjoy an evening stroll on the Tour Road.

images.title: Wilson's Creek National Battlefield Visitor Center
images.altText: Front Entrance of Visitor Center and Arrowhead on sign reading "Wilson's Creek National Battlefield"
images.caption: Begin your visit at the newly remodeled Visitor Center at Wilson's Creek National Battlefield.

images.title: The Lyon Bed
images.altText: General Nathaniel Lyon killed at  The Battle of Wilson's Creek was placed on this bed. The Lyon Bed.
images.caption: The Bed where General Nathaniel Lyon is placed, after being fatally wounded on the Battlefield.

data.weatherInfo: Summer months are frequently hot and humid, with occasional showers and thunderstorms. Winter months (especially January and February) are frequently cold, with occasional ice and light snow. Spring and fall months are generally pleasant, with occasional showers.
data.name: Wilson's Creek
